fields.description:
I just installed the new version of crowd and came across a JavaScript error on CROWD_PICKER.
After a bit of research I found that this JavaScript object is created in entity_picker.js which is include in the body of several pages.

{code}
crowd-webapp\console\secure\directory\view_connector_options.jsp
   Line 111 :     <script type="text/javascript" src="/crowd/console/js/entity_picker.js"></script>
crowd-webapp\console\secure\directory\view_delegated_options.jsp
   Line 111 :     <script type="text/javascript" src="/crowd/console/js/entity_picker.js"></script>
crowd-webapp\console\secure\directory\view_internal_options.jsp
   Line 107 :     <script type="text/javascript" src="/crowd/console/js/entity_picker.js"></script>
crowd-webapp\console\secure\group\view_group_members.jsp
   Line 216 :     <script type="text/javascript" src="/crowd/console/js/entity_picker.js"></script>
crowd-webapp\console\secure\principal\view_principal.jsp
   Line 536 :     <script type="text/javascript" src="/crowd/console/js/entity_picker.js"></script>
{code}
As shown is the src of the script hardcoded and not aware of any server context.
I'm currently running crowd in the root context ({{so just http://localhost:8085/}}) and ofcourse then crowd/console/js/entity_picker.js can't be found.

This results in a JavaScript error and I'm not able to add groups or users which to existing groups. which makes crowd sort of useless for me.

Of course I can fix this just by changed the template files, but I'm sure more people will have this problem
fields.summary: entity_picker.js include not aware of server context

fields.description:
Currently, if a Crowd instance is running with an in-memory token table that's not large enough for the number of concurrent sessions, tokens will be kicked out and sessions will appear to expire for no good reason.

We don't provide a log message to help sysadmins determine what's happening. This ain't good.
fields.summary: Provide a log message if tokens are evicted from in-memory cache due to cache filling up

fields.description:
[http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Session+Configuration] tells customers how to switch between database-backed and in-memory token caching.

What it does not (yet) do is help customers to size the cache to the number of concurrent sessions they expect to have. The documentation should be updated with this info.

(This issue will shortly be updated w/ our internal configuration so we can provide a concrete example in the docs; this issue can lie dormant 'til then).
fields.summary: Document cache sizings for in-memory token caches

fields.description:
Currently it is not possible, through the existing client API, to implement a custom timeout time.

You may consider returning a token object () with such attributes. This functionality exists in SUN's Access Manager. For example see:
http://docs.sun.com/source/816-6824-10/com/iplanet/sso/SSOToken.html

This may also solve CWD-1171.
fields.summary: Customizable timeouts - Add 'idleTime' or 'lastAccessed' field to client SOAP API (e.g. SecurityServerClient)

fields.description:
There's a bug in the Crowd Apache connector to do with the relative timeouts on the validity of app tokens. If the cache expiry time in the Apache connector is longer than the expiry time of the app token in Crowd, then the connector will use an expired app token (which it thinks is still valid) to authenticate principals. The problem is that when this principal authentication fails (which it will, because the app token is no longer valid), the apache connector doesn't dump the app token cache because it thinks that the authentication failed because the principal credentials were wrong.

This bug is easy to work around: always set the Apache connector expiry to something less than the Crowd server expiry.

(see CWDSUP-2050)
fields.summary: CrowdAuth doesn't expire cached app tokens if CrowdAuth timeout longer than Crowd timeout

fields.description:
Prior to the 2.0 release of Crowd Group names were case sensitive in the Internal Directory. This meant that it was possible to have two groups with the same theoretical name 'CROWD-administrators' and 'crowd-administrators' in an internal directory. To fix this issue in 2.0 the decision was made to make all group names lowercase and have a uniqueness constraint on the groupname+directoryid to stop the ability to have two groups with the same name in Crowd.

Migrating our users to 2.0 it was decided that all groups would be lowercased on import and we would check for potential duplicates and die-hard if an error was found.

This can affect integrated apps that currently contain references to mixed-case group names.
fields.summary: Internal Directory group names in 2.x are lower case by design and incompatible with 1.x

fields.description:
Permission to Add/Update/Delete 'role' uses the permissions set for 'group' rather than the permissions set for 'role'.

Applicable in both ApplicationServerGeneric and DirectoryManagerGeneric
fields.summary: Roles observe group permissioning as opposed to role permissioning

fields.description:
As I administer the configuration of various application services (such as Jira and Confluence etc.) I would like to let my users know about it.  Unfortunately my Crowd group information is not available in my corporate email system (in my case, Lotus Notes) and it is too large to enter manually.

What I would like to have is the ability to create an ad-hoc email for system notices (text-only is good enough) within crowd and email it out to one or more groups (duplicate emails should be pruned)

This need could also be satisfied with some way to export user group data to all possible email systems (but I think that might be a bit prohibitive given the sheer number of mail systems out there)

I personally would be OK with only crowd-administrators getting to use the email notice facility, but it might be OK to have some way to allow other groups to be allowed to do the same.
fields.summary: Create and send ad-hoc notice email to one or more Crowd groups
Make sure the current Console Administrator cannot unassign a group from the Crowd console that would stop them accessing the console.

fields.description:
The REST API could offer list of services for requests sent to the root URL.

For example, if the request URL is the root:
{code:html}
http://localhost:8095/crowd/rest/admin/latest/
{code}
or 
{code:html}
http://localhost:8095/crowd/rest/admin/1/
{code}

Then the response could contain the list of available services, something like:
{code:xml}
<resources>
  <resource name="directory">
    <link rel="self" href="http://localhost:8095/crowd/rest/admin/latest/directory" />
  </resource>
<resource name="login">
    <link rel="self" href="http://localhost:8095/crowd/rest/admin/latest/login" />
  </resource>
</resources>
{code}

Bamboo is planning something similar. See the [docs|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/REV230+-+Bamboo+REST+Resources].
fields.summary: REST API could offer list of services for requests sent to the root URL

fields.description:
The token storage state is being persisted correctly in the database but the instance of the TokenDAOProxy ignores the stored property.

We need to make sure the TokenDAOProxy switches it's implementation based on the persisted property after a successful XML restore operation.
fields.summary: Restoring from an XML backup that used in-memory tokens will revert back to database backed tokens

fields.description:
Updating a groups's attributes requires a remove then add of common attributes. Two inserts can happen simultaneously due to the read committed isolation level on the database. This error only manifests itself under high concurrent mutation of the attributes on the exact same group (ie. extremely rare).

We currently do not expose group attributes via the Crowd Console UI, but there's potential here for errors to occur if users have extended Crowd to access these attributes.
fields.summary: Updating group attributes causes database error
REST API error response body should be XML by default

fields.description: Updating a user's attributes requires a remove then add of common attributes. The remove can, in some circumstances, get flushed after the add. This causes a constraint violation as the add happens before the remove.
fields.summary: Updating user attributes causes database error

fields.description:
*When using IE 8*, clicking the "Disable Roles" checkbox does not immediately hide/reveal the role configuration fields.

To reproduce:
# Open the Crowd Admin Console using IE 8.
# Go to "*Directories*" and open an LDAP directory connector.
# Go to the "*Configuration*" tab.
# Remove the tick from the "*Disable Roles*" checkbox --- nothing happens. You have to click the "*Update*" button or tab out of the field, then the role config fields appear. Similarly, the fields should disappear if you put a tick into the "*Disable Roles*" checkbox.

(In *Firefox 3*, the role config fields _are_ immediately revealed when you untick the "Disable Roles" checkbox, and the fields _are_ immediately hidden when you tick the "Disable Roles" checkbox. This is the expected behaviour.)
fields.summary: Clicking the "Disable Roles" checkbox should immediately hide/reveal the role configuration fields

fields.description:

Currently, Crowd provides to the Applications: Login and Password, First and Last Names, Email.

Would be good to be able to create more fields in an Internal Directory and then make the data available to the Integrated Applications.

The same for the LDAP Connectors. All the LDAP attributes shall be available and editable from the APPs.
fields.summary: Allow Admins to add more fields to Internal Directories and fetch more attributes from LDAP in order to provide a more complete user data set to the Integrated Applications

fields.description:
Creating a user without a password is not possible in Crowd. The clients will get an exception if trying to do this (expected behaviour).

The Problem is that JIRA, Confluence, Bamboo, etc requires the ability to add a user without a password being supplied, due to the OSUser and AtlassianUser interfaces.
fields.summary: Creating a user via an atlassian-user based applicaiton fails because a password is not supplied on user creation

fields.description:
I used the CSV importer to import users (*see attached file:"users1"*) and memberships (*see attached file:"memberships1"*) into an empty internal directory ("employees").

The import ran without a problem. At the end, the "Results" screen reported:
Users: 2
Groups: 4
Memberships: 3

However, the log reports 2 users, 4 groups and 5 memberships. There are no errors in the log, as far as I can see. *See attached log file.*

In my database, the 2 users imported correctly and were converted to lower case.
The 4 groups imported correctly and were converted to lower case.
The group membership import failed for the mixed-case user/groups ({{justinkoke}}), but was successful for the lower-case user/groups({{joesmith}}).
*See attached database export XML file.*
fields.summary: Import from CSV is not case-insensitive for adding memberships

fields.description:
Now that we're approaching the release of Crowd 2.0, the help links in 1.6 should be redirected to the CROWD016 space.

Please update the .htaccess file to redirect the help calls from Crowd 1.6 to the CROWD016 space, and to send help calls from Crowd 2.0 to the CROWD space.

Reference: https://extranet.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Updating+Help+Links
fields.summary: Configure redirection of context-sensitive online help links for existing 1.6 release and new 2.0 release

fields.description:
Crowd 2.0 has a new "Users" tab in the application management screens, that shows all the users in all directories mapped to a given application. You can search for a user by name, username or email address. The results show user details for each matching user, including alias. See screenshot.

It would be nice to be able to search by alias too, restricting the search to the aliases for the selected application.
fields.summary: Application "Users" tab should allow search on alias

fields.description: As from Crowd 2.0, you can user an IP address range in CIDR notation when specifying an application's IP addresses. This works on the application "Remote Addresses" tab when updating an existing application. But when adding an application, you have to enter a single IP address on the "2. Connection" step. See attached screenshot. Should you be able to add an IP range here too?
fields.summary: When adding an application, you should be able to enter an IP address range

fields.description:
When using IE 7, the "Add Groups" button is too close to the bottom line on the directory "Options" tab. See attached screenshot.

The placement of the button is fine when using Firefox 3.
fields.summary: The "Add Groups" button is too close to the bottom line on the directory "Options" tab

fields.description:
The application "Options" tab has some text with a link to the documentation. The text is:
{quote}With aliasing enabled, users can have a different username (alias) for the "demo" application. This is useful if "demo" does not support user renaming. See the documentation.{quote}

The word "documentation" is currently linked to http://this.really.needs.to.go.somewhere.com.au/

Instead, please:
* Hook this link up to the help-paths.properties file, so that it supports our version control. 
* Make it open in a new browser window/tab.
* Point the link to the following page: Specifying+a+User%27s+Aliases

(http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Specifying+a+User%27s+Aliases)
fields.summary: Fix link in UI text pointing to docs on application "Options" tab

fields.description:
Please would you fill in the gaps in the documentation of REST resources for Crowd 2.0:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/REST+Resources

There's some red text on the page, showing where we have not been able to test the REST API and document it yet. In particular
* The "authentication (login)" resource.
* The PUT, POST and DELETE actions for {{/directory/DIRECTORY-KEY/user }} and {{/directory/DIRECTORY-KEY/user/USER-KEY }}
* The real URL for group member list and group member information.
* Describe how to retrieve nested groups, and how to add/remove them.
* Have we documented all available resources?

Additional requirement for the resources page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/REST+Resources
We need to add the XML required for POST operations, such as when adding a user. We've asked the reader to assume the SML is similar to the get request. This requires a process of trial and error to get the right input.
fields.summary: Fill in the gaps in the documentation of REST resources

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 28 January 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We are pleased to announce that we have released support for OpenID Connect for Jira, Confluence, Bitbucket and Jira Service Desk Data Center.

You can learn more about it here: [https://www.atlassian.com/blog/enterprise/openid-connect]

Please note that in order to use OpenID Connect you will need Data Center license.

You can create your evaluation license for your Data Center product here [https://my.atlassian.com/license/evaluation]

We hope that you will enjoy it!

Please reply directly to my email to share your feedback or just add your comments in this ticket. We'd love to hear your thoughts!

Best regards,

Marek Radochonski
 Senior Product Manager
 [mradochonski@atlassian.com|mailto:mradochonski@atlassian.com]
{panel}


Your colleague, Renan Battaglin, suggested that I open this feature request (ref. https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CWDSUP-1991)

Currently, Crowd is able to act as an OpenID Provider, through CrowdID.

It would be nice if Crowd could also act as a Relying Party, so people could authenticate with Crowd using their AOL, Yahoo! or other external OpenID.

Authenticating with an external OpenId should give access to the Atlassian services corresponding to the user's Crowd profile. That is, it should work as if the external OpenID were a CrowdId. It might be necessary that an administrator creates the Crowd profile for the user, but it should be an option to use an OpenID from an external provider to log in to this profile.

This would allow sites running Atlassian products with SSO through Crowd to offer their users the ability to re-use their existing OpenID, rather than creating a new one with Crowd (which somewhat defeats the whole idea of a single OpenId to log in to multiple services and sites).
fields.summary: Let people authenticate with an OpenID from an external OpenID provider (like AOL, Yahoo!,...)

fields.description:
During the setup wizard, if one inputs an invalid hostname when configuring the Base URL, crowd installation will halt and fail to continue.


h5. Work around:
_Shutdown Crowd, delete the Crowd-Home-Directory and then Restart Crowd_

Deleting the Crowd-Home-Directory will force the installation wizard to start again form scratch. Go through the installation steps and at step 6, instead of the URL previously provided, keep the default value: http://localhost:8095.
fields.summary: Setup wizard should check base URL before continuing

fields.description: We need a possibility to rename groups from the Admin pages.
fields.summary: Ability to rename groups
REST API returns HTTP 403 if search parameter not included in URL

fields.description:
In the REST API, the URL below returns two levels of the {{<directories>}} element. Instead, the lower level should be {{<directory>}}:

URL:
{code:html}http://localhost:8095/crowd/rest/admin/latest/directory{code}

Returns something like this:
{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes" ?> 
- <directories>
- <directories>
  <name>Active Directory</name> 
  <type>CONNECTOR</type> 
  <implementationClass>com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.connector.MicrosoftActiveDirectory</implementationClass> 
  </directories>
- <directories>
  <name>Atlassian Crowd</name> 
  <type>INTERNAL</type> 
  <implementationClass>com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.internal.InternalDirectory</implementationClass> 
  </directories>
- <directories>
  <name>Crowd Internal</name> 
  <type>INTERNAL</type> 
  <implementationClass>com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.internal.InternalDirectory</implementationClass> 
  </directories>
- <directories>
  <name>Delegated Auth Directory</name> 
  <type>DELEGATING</type> 
  <implementationClass>com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.delegated.DelegatedAuthenticationDirectory</implementationClass> 
  </directories>
- <directories>
  <name>Employees</name> 
  <type>INTERNAL</type> 
  <implementationClass>com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.internal.InternalDirectory</implementationClass> 
  </directories>
- <directories>
  <name>My Own Connector</name> 
  <type>CUSTOM</type> 
  <implementationClass>com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.custom.MyOwnConnector</implementationClass> 
  </directories>
  </directories>
{code}
fields.summary: REST "directory" resource returns two levels of "<directories>" element

fields.description:
When updating aliases for multiple applications at once, if there is 1+ invalid update it causes some problems.
eg.
If invalid alias is first application, aliases after that will not be updated.
If invalid alias is the last application, aliases before that will be updated, but the update is not evident until user refershes the page.
fields.summary: Updating aliases with a mix of valid/invalid update can cause strange behaviour

fields.description:
Hello,

within certain organizations it would be very convenient to be able to authenticate users with x509 certificates. I also opened a corresponding request for JIRA ([JRA-17795|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-17795]) but it would be also useful to offer this feature through SSO.



Best Regards,
Edoardo
fields.summary: x509 client certificate Authentication and Authorization support

fields.description:
Currently, JIRA and Confluence don't display the User Fist Name and Last Name in different fields. They fetch Crowd's displayName data and display as the User Full Name.

When the User information is updated using JIRA/Confluence consoles, Crowd App Connectors will split the Full Name and update its internal displayName, First Name and Last Name fields.

It works fine if the displayName field was originally storing the name using the following format:

First Last (Ex: John Smith)

However it can be a problem when handling a displayName like the following:

Last, First (Ex: Smith, John)

When the APP connector saves the information in Crowd the followin happens:

First Name: Smith,
Last Name: John

Would be good to be able to set in Crowd what displayName format is being used in each Directory.
fields.summary: Allow the Crowd Integration Client App Connectors to support different Full Name representations

fields.description:
The "Direct Members" tab in group management has an awesome new user picker for Crowd 2.1. The user picker allows you to search for users by entering all or part of a username or email address into the search box. However, it does not attempt to match on name.

It would be great to add the full name to the matching, so that this search behaves in the same way as the one on the User Browser screen ({{.../console/secure/user/browse.action}}}).
fields.summary: The search in the new user picker in group management does not match on name

fields.description:
The new "Add Group" wizard on the User "Groups" tab changes the online help link for that tab.

When you first enter the tab, the online help link points to "Editing a User's Group and Role Membership" as expected. But after using the group picker, the help link points to "Editing a User's Details and Password".
fields.summary: Help link is wrong after use of the "Add Group" wizard on the User "Groups" tab

fields.description:
The new "Users" tab in application management currently shows am empty list of users if any one of the directories is unavailable, even if other directories are available and mapped to the application.

Instead, perhaps the "Users" tab should show the error message from the unavailable directory. And perhaps it should list the users that are available in the available directories.

To reproduce:
* I currently have my "demo" app mapped to an internal directory and to Active Directory. My Active Directory is giving an error when I click the "Test Search" button on the directory "Configuration" tab. But on the application's "Users" tab I just see an empty list.
* If I remove the mapping of Active Directory from my app but retain the internal directory, then the "Users" tab shows the list of users from the internal directory.


BTW, the error I'm getting on my LDAP directory is as follows (in case this is useful for the above problem):
{quote}No results were found from your search. [LDAP: error code 4 - Sizelimit Exceeded]; nested exception is javax.naming.SizeLimitExceededException: [LDAP: error code 4 - Sizelimit Exceeded]; remaining name 'dc=sydney,dc=atlassian,dc=com'
{quote}
fields.summary: Application "Users" tab does not show any users if one directory is unavailable

fields.description:
Currently {{addAllUsers}} and {{addAllGroups}} on the {{DirectoryManager}} will not fire any {{UserCreatedEvents}} or {{GroupCreatedEvents}}. This was specifically disabled for performance reasons.

We need to benchmark the impact of firing these events, especially within the context of the {{AutoGroupAdderListener}} that specifically listens to these events. If the performance issues are manageable, then we should fire these events for bulk operations.
fields.summary: Fire user/group created events for user bulk add operations
Make sure the current Console Administrator cannot unassign a directory from the Crowd console that would remove them as a Crowd administrator
Make sure the current Console administrator cannot delete a directory they are currently authenticated from
Make sure the current Console administrator cannot remove themselves from a group that will no longer make them a console administrator

fields.description: Table names are currently upper case. To match our other products (like JIRA) we will change the convention to lower case table names.
fields.summary: Lower-case table and column names for Crowd 2.0 schema
Make sure the current user cannot delete themselves from Crowd

fields.description: From 2.0 onwards, we're happy to officially support Tomcat 6.
fields.summary: Document that we now officially support Tomcat 6.

fields.description:
Operations other than group membership should be doable in bulk.

Examples: deleting, disabling, resetting password.
fields.summary: Bulk non-group-membership operations on users

fields.description: Searching for all users whose favourite color is blue. Or, searching for all users that have a Jabber ID set.
fields.summary: Allow searching for users by custom attributes

fields.description: The pager does not appear on the group browser (ie. next/previous buttons not present).
fields.summary: Paging missing on group browser

fields.description:
Currently we cannot expect a username string in JIRA "justin" to equal the username string "justin@atlassian.com" in Confluence.

For trusted apps to work JIRA and Confluence need to have both users to have the same name. 

With Application aliasing in Crowd we have complicated matters some what in allowing "justin" in JIRA to equal "justin@atlassian.com" in Confluence. However if their is a trust relationship between both these applications the 'trust' will fail for this user.

This requires work to make the UserResolver in trusted apps 'plugable/configurable' so Crowd can correctly translate one username to another username for these requests.
fields.summary: Trusted Applications + Application Aliasing will not work in Crowd. We need trusted applications to be 'enhanced' so we can provide a configurable user provider.

fields.description:
Currently the SearchContext approach used for searching in Crowd is very poor and ill defined.

We need a better approach that is:
# Type Safe
# Can handle AND OR queries
# Can support nested queries.
fields.summary: RemoteDirectory requires a more advanced search API to replace the current SearchContext approach used in the SecurityServer

fields.description:
If you have an internal/delegated directory without nested groups, then you should be able to improve performance by switching off "nested groups".

It is expected that the improvement in performance will be roughly proportional to the number of groups in directory (ie. reduce {{n}} JDBC calls where {{n}} is the number of groups in the directory).
fields.summary: Allow the ability to switch off nested groups for internal and delegated directories

fields.description:
When you search for a user/group and need to apply a disjunctive restriction to attributes, it is possible that the same entity will be returned twice in the result set. This is why a SELECT DISTINCT is performed. Internally, the DISTINCT operation on the database could generally be implemented by using sort on all fields prior to a cull. This process is expensive.

Since we only need to DISTINCT when we do a join with a custom attributes table, we should optimise for the non-custom-attribute restriction path and not DISTINCT unless custom attributes are involved.
fields.summary: HQLQueryTranslator needs to review usages of "distinct"

fields.description:
Shall we add some help links to our 4 new popup screens in the group management section of the Admin Console? These are the new popup boxes from the "*Direct Members*" tab, allowing you to add/remove users and sub-groups.
# "Add Groups" popup screen --- link to page: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Adding+a+Sub-Group
# "Remove Groups" popup screen --- link to page: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Removing+a+Sub-Group
# "Add Users" popup screen --- link to page: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Adding+Users+to+a+Group
# "Remove Users" popup screen --- link to page: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Removing+Users+from+a+Group

This will involve the following changes:
* Add the help links to UI.
* Update {{help-paths.properties}} file.
* Write the docs --- In progress; pages are already available for linking to. (See links above.)
fields.summary: Add some help links to the new Group Management popup screens

fields.description:
As part of our Directory Server configuration we specify password policies allowing things such as grace logins, notification of impending password expiry, etc. In LDAP, if any of these cases arise (eg: password due to expire in 7 days) we would typically get a set of controls returned as part of the InitialLdapContext that would contain this information.

Crowd should support access to and propagation of this information.
fields.summary: Propagate state from LDAP custom controls through Crowd (eg "password about to expire")
Test Trusted Application support with Aliased applications

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Crowd+Database+Schema

(/) Please assign this issue to a developer
fields.summary: Update the  database schema documentation for Crowd 2.0

fields.description:
Some LDAP directories (eg Microsoft Active Directory) support the concept of an active/inactive user. For those directories, we should make this information available within Crowd.

Other directories will continue to report all users as active and will error when attempting to modify the active status.
fields.summary: Support active flag for LDAP directories
Create Crowd 2.0 artifact

The "Direct Members" tab has two section headings: "*Group Members*" and "*User Members*". See attached screenshot.

fields.description:
Apache DS 1.0.2 does not cleanly support searching via filters.

e.g. The following filter will return no results, even though there are matches:
{code}
(&
    (objectclass=inetorgperson)
    (|
        (sn=*jdoe@testingarea.org*)
        (mail=*jdoe@testingarea.org*)
        (displayname=*jdoe@testingarea.org*)
    )
)
{code}
No results are returned because the displayname attribute does not exist on the users.

The same filter will execute fine with Apache DS 1.5.4.
fields.summary: Apache DS 1.0.2 support for searching in Crowd 2.0

fields.summary: Shuffling the order of directories on an application causes Hibernate exception

fields.description:
To reproduce the problem:
Having JIRA, Crowd and OpenLDAP integrated, do the following:
1-) Create a new group using JIRA's Console
2-) Try to delete the created Group using JIRA console
3-) The operation will be successful, but the Group name will not be removed from the Groups list
4-) Check the LDAP server. The Group was deleted.
5-) If JIRA is restarted, the Group will stop being displayed.

Similar to CWD-1080, but happens to JIRA only.
Also similar to CWD-667, however it happens to groups only.
fields.summary: Crowd Client Cache is not refreshed when a Group is deleted using JIRA Admin console

fields.description:
Hello.

When adding an application in Crowd there are often default groups that are required. 

JIRA, for instance, requires jira-users, jira-developers, jira-administrators and jira-system-administrators.

Confluence requires confluence-administrators and confluence-users.

If these groups could be added automatically that would be super, one less step.

Thank You.
Nick
fields.summary: When adding an application, create the required groups
